discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
In this scenario, the laptop has an IP address that doesn’t belong to the corporate network IP scheme. This is more indicative of a DHCP issue rather than an Evil Twin attack. An Evil Twin attack would typically result in the user being connected to a malicious network, not just having an incorrect IP address. Therefore, the most likely cause of the issue in this case is DHCP exhaustion, not an Evil Twin (A). In an evil twin attack, an attacker sets up a rogue wireless access point with a name and settings that mimic a legitimate corporate network. Users may inadvertently connect to this rogue access point, thinking it's the legitimate network, and the attacker can then intercept or manipulate their traffic. However, this attack doesn't directly involve the allocation of IP addresses.

Selected Answer: A
The keywords here that indicate that it's A are "Wireless Network" and "Client has an IP assignment" but that assignment is in another range.

I could see this as being either A or C
An evil twin is a fraudulent Wi-Fi access point that appears to be legitimate but is set up to eavesdrop on wireless communications.
So A could be right if the laptop connected to a different Wifi.

C could also be right, because the IP address could be APIPA, making it so they can't connect

A.Evil Twin Attack (ETA) refers to a rogue Wi-Fi Access Point (AP) that appears to be a legitimate one but actually has been set up to eavesdrop on wireless communications [1]. Most of existing detection techniques assume that the attacker will use the same legitimate wireless network gateway to pass through victim’s wireless data. These detection methods will fail if the attacker uses a different gateway, such as using his own broadband cellular connection through his own smartphone. In this paper, we present a new client-side detection method to detect such an ETA that uses a different gateway from the legitimate one. It relies on SSL/TCP connection to an arbitrary remote web server to avoid attacker’s misleading message, and trying to detect the changing of gateway’s public IP address by switching from one AP to another in the middle of the SSL/TCP connection. The detection method is on the client side which makes it more convenient for users to deploy and ensure their security. Index Terms—Evil Twin Attack, Wi-Fi security, TCP, SSL.
Checking the IP address on the laptop or the wireless AP? Ok, lets say the tech checks the laptop. Why not assumed C is the answer and has been assigned an APIPA address?

comments.content: The main reason why I was able to get A as the answer is because it doesn't mention that an APIPA address is assigned, and says the address it has isn't in the scope provided by their servers.

discussion.content: This can actually also be C. If an APIPA address has been assigned to the laptop, it can be due to DHCP exhaustion. The question doesn't explicitly say as well that an attack was happening.

questions.question_text: A network technician arrives at a remote office and is unable to connect a laptop to corporate resources using the wireless network. After checking the IP address, the network technician notices the assigned IP address does not belong to the corporate network IP scheme. Which of the following has the network technician discovered?
Which of the following is an object held within an MIB?

discussion.content: Everything on a device that can be monitored by SNMP is assigned an object identifier. a management information base translates OID into readable text.

A management information base (MIB) is a database used for managing the entities in a communication network, most often associated with the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP).

In the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP), OID means an "Object Identifier." To define OID, it's an address used to uniquely identify managed devices and their statuses.

questions.question_text: Which of the following storage network technologies has the HIGHEST throughput?

discussion.content:
From highest throughput to lowest:

InfiniBand (IB) is a computer networking communications standard used in high-performance computing that features very high throughput and very low latency. 

Fibre Channel over Ethernet (FCoE) is a computer network technology that encapsulates Fibre Channel frames over Ethernet networks, and is a low-latency, high-bandwidth, high-throughput protocol.

iSCSI was created as a lower cost, lower performance alternative to Fibre Channel that uses standard Ethernet switches and cabling

OC-3 is a network line on theSynchronous Optical Networking (SONET) fiber optic network with transmission data rate of up to 155.52 Mbit/s
Thank you, Callas, for your explanations.
Am I only one who counts this on his fingers
/25 = 00000000.00000000.00000000.10000000 = 7 host bits = 128 hosts. This is enough to cover 70 devices for the finance department. etc. Answer is C.

comments.content: correction 111111111.11111111.11111111.10000000. network bit has to be turned on. : )
but for HR that /27that will give you 32 hosts, & it should be at least 38.. I dont get it :/

actually it's 62 available hosts. Finance: 126, Human: 62 and I.T. will be 30. So that will be /25, /26 and /27 respectively. I look at it as the lower the CIDR the less hosts....so when I see /28, /29 and /30...you know that you don't have to waste your energy computing these.
HR is /26 which is 64 hosts. It only needs 32 so /26 is more enough. I think you just got them confused.

questions.question_text:
The corporate head office has assigned the subnet of 10.1.100.0/24 to a network technician. The technician wants to create subnets for the finance department, human resources, and IT. Given the following device counts:

Finance: 70 devices -

Human resources: 38 devices -

IT: 16 devices -
Which of the following outlines how the technician should allocate the address space given?

discussion.content: minus 2 for the network and broadcast address
/22 = 11111111.11111111.11111100.00000000 = 1024 host - 2 network ID and broadcast = 1022 available host

comments.content: Hosts that are "supported" can be implied as usable hosts
you forgetting that formula: 2 to the tenth power will give you 1024, but you have to minus . Therefore your answer should be 1022.

discussion.content: Wouldn't the answer be 1024, because the question does not specify between number of hosts and number of 'usable' hosts?
1024 less broadcast and network address is 1022 is the answer
The correct answer is 1024. Its 2 to the power of 10 host bits.

comments.content: You are close, but don't forget to take away 2 hosts for NID and BID. So, the correct answer is 1024 - 2 = 1022.
" Which of the following is the number of 'hosts' that will be supported"

questions.question_text: A network administrator is configuring the 172.16.40.0/22 network for a new building. Which of the following is the number of hosts that will be supported on this network?
